newsitem.title: CHILE: Codelco's Salvador pit closes face, cuts jobs.
newsitem.headline: Codelco's Salvador pit closes face, cuts jobs.

text.p: Chilean state copper company Codelco's Salvador mine will shut down one of its oldest areas mid-year due to falling grades and geological problems, but the closure will not hurt copper output, said a division spokesman.

The problems led the division to bring forward the closure of the area, known as Granito, which had been programmed for the end of 1997 or mid 1998, spokesman Aldo Siri told Reuters by telephone from the mine.
"The constantly sliding (ore) grades meant it wasn't worth trying to solve the geo-mechanical difficulties," said Siri.
The shut-down will not hurt the pit's copper output as new areas of the main Inca pit are being brought on-line which will make up for the lost production, said Siri.
The closure will cost up to 250 jobs, but Codelco does not expect any labor problems as the job cuts are under discussion with the pit's unions, said Siri.
The mine reported output of 89,841 tonnes last year and expects production to rise to 100,000 tonnes by 2000, he said.
"We expect output to reach 100,000 tonnes once the heap-leaching plant in is full operation and there have been adjustments in the mine and refinery," said Siri.
The 25,000-tonne heapleaching plant has yet to reach full capacity because of technical problems which have plagued it since start-up two years ago. It produced 18,428 tonnes in 1996.
